div.p: Greetings. Three days ago, most illustrious man, I received your letters, in which were those you sent from Poland.
Yesterday, I took that bundle to Mr. Calvin: he himself read through those written by Mr. Stanislaus, from whom he had also recently received letters.
He briefly glanced at two other writings, but did not read them thoroughly.
At the end of another writing, he laughed at the threats of Gregorius Paulus.
Mr. Beza was present.
Finally, he said that he had already briefly responded to the vain imaginations and absurdities of those people.
He did not add anything else at that time.

Today, when our Linettus returned from Lyon, he responded to Mr. Stanislaus with a few words regarding what he asked, and referred him to his Admonition and Epistle, unless he prefers to seek a more detailed treatment of this matter from his other books.
Finally, he writes that it will happen that this Gregorius will extort something.
This is the summary of the letters, and he resolves the question of invocation in a few words.
A copy, which is very brief, will be sent to you, if it seems appropriate.
Moreover, I hope to write something against Stancarus at some point.
I am now returning those Polish letters.
Indeed, I would have gladly taken down and sent to you anything more he might have dictated or said about that controversy: but you know the brevity of the man.
If you think my assistance might be useful to you in any other matter, I will gladly comply.
In your name, I greeted Mr. Calvin, Mr. Beza, Budaeus, and others, who all respectfully greet you.
I wish all of yours to be safe.
May the Lord keep you safe for a long time, guide you with His spirit, and bless your labors.
Geneva, September 12, 1563.
Charles de Jonvilliers, your most observant.
To the most illustrious Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, faithful pastor of the Church of Zurich, whom I hold in great esteem.
Zurich.
